historicalName: Calle dei Carmelitani in Sestiere di Dorsoduro
englishName: Carmelite Friars' Street in the Dorsoduro District
historicalDescription: A street located near the Church and Monastery of Santa Maria dei Carmini, home to Carmelite friars. The area was known for its religious institutions and residential neighborhoods in the 15th century.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the Carmelite monks who established their convent in Dorsoduro during the 14th century. This fondamenta would have been the main landing dock for supplies and visitors to the Carmelite monastery.
Named after the nearby Church of San Barnaba in Dorsoduro, founded in the 9th century. This dock would have served parishioners and clergy attending services and religious festivals.
Dorsoduro was home to many artisan workshops, including sculptors who would receive marble and stone deliveries via this dock for their commissions in churches and palazzi throughout Venice.

Named after the popular sweet wine imported from Greece. This dock would have been used by merchants selling this coveted beverage, which was particularly popular among Venetian nobility in the Renaissance period.

A landing place for the barcaroli, professional boatmen who operated small vessels for hire. Near Calle dei Carmelitani, this dock would have been a gathering point for gondoliers and other small boat operators.

Named after the prominent Santa Maria dei Carmini church in Dorsoduro, built by Carmelite friars. This dock would have been used for processions and for bringing religious artifacts and materials to the church.

Named for the Procurators of St. Mark, high-ranking Venetian officials who may have maintained property in this area. This dock would have served administrative functions for the Republic's officials.
Near an institution established in 1557 for housing and converting Jews and Muslims to Christianity. This dock would have been the arrival point for those entering the catechumenate in Dorsoduro.
Named after a nearby squero (traditional Venetian boatyard) where gondolas were built and repaired. This dock would have received timber and other materials for boat construction.
Named for the guild of knife makers who had workshops in this area of Dorsoduro. This dock would have been used for receiving metal shipments and for distributing their finished products.

Dedicated to the skilled artisans who carved decorative elements for furniture, gondolas, and architectural features. This dock would have been used for transporting valuable woods and finished pieces.

Though the Frari church is in San Polo, this dock in Dorsoduro could have served as a connection point for Franciscan friars traveling between monasteries, reflecting the religious network that existed in Renaissance Venice.
Named simply for the residents of the Dorsoduro district, this communal dock would have been used by locals for daily transportation and receiving household goods.
Named after a small customs point where goods entering this part of Dorsoduro would be inspected and taxed. The term 'toletta' refers to the small toll or tax collected here.
Dedicated to traders in linen and flax products who operated in this area of Dorsoduro. This dock would have received raw materials and exported finished textiles.
Named for German merchants who had established a presence in this part of Venice. This dock would have facilitated trade between Venice and German-speaking territories.

Referencing one of Venice's important confraternities that may have owned property near Calle dei Carmelitani. These charitable organizations played a crucial role in Renaissance Venetian social welfare.
Named after the Church of Sant'Agnese that once stood in Dorsoduro. This dock would have served the parish and visitors to religious celebrations honoring the saint.
Named after a nobili family that owned property in Dorsoduro during the Renaissance. Family-named docks were common in Venice, indicating ownership or patronage of that waterfront area.

Named for bakers specializing in biscotti and hardtack, essential provisions for Venetian ships on long voyages. This dock would have been used to load these durable foodstuffs onto vessels departing Venice.
Named after decorative small towers that may have characterized buildings in this part of Dorsoduro. Architectural features often provided inspiration for place names in Renaissance Venice.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the Carmelite friars who had their monastery nearby in Dorsoduro. The Carmelite Order established a significant presence in this area during the Renaissance period, influencing local religious life and architecture.

This bridge would reference the stonemasons who likely worked in this area of Dorsoduro during the Renaissance. Many craftsmen and artisans were concentrated in specific neighborhoods, and stonemasons would have been essential for Venetian construction projects.

Named after a historical kiln or furnace that would have operated in this area of Dorsoduro. Venice had numerous furnaces for producing glass, ceramics, and bricks, essential materials for the city's construction and famous craft industries.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the glassmakers who had workshops in this area of Dorsoduro. Though Murano was the center of Venetian glass production, some glassmakers maintained smaller workshops in this part of the city.

Named after the Jesuate religious order who established a church in Dorsoduro. The church of Santa Maria dei Gesuati (later known as Santa Maria del Rosario) was an important landmark in this sestiere.

Named after the Church of San Nicolò da Tolentino in the nearby area. 'Rio Terà' indicates this was once a canal that was filled in to create a street, a common practice in Venice's urban development.
This name refers to a warehouse or storage facility that existed in this area of Dorsoduro. Many such facilities were essential to Venice's commercial activities during the Renaissance.
Named after a convent that was located nearby. Salizada indicates this was one of the first paved streets in the area, showing its importance for local movement of people and goods.
A covered passageway near the Carmelite church (Chiesa del Carmine) in Dorsoduro. This name directly relates to the Carmelitani mentioned in the reference location.
Named after one of Venice's Scuole Grandi (Great Schools), which were important confraternities and charitable organizations during the Renaissance. Dorsoduro housed several of these institutions.
Named after the wooden rafts that would dock along this waterfront in Dorsoduro. This was a major landing area for timber that was floated down from the Alpine regions.
Named after the friars who lived in a monastery near this street in Dorsoduro. Religious orders were prominent in Venetian urban geography.
Named after the nearby Campo Santa Margherita, one of the largest squares in Dorsoduro. This was once a canal that was filled in, as the 'Rio Terà' designation indicates.
Named after the Ospedale degli Incurabili, a hospital founded in the 16th century that treated patients with syphilis and other diseases considered incurable at the time. It was located in Dorsoduro.
Named after a charitable institution that provided assistance to the poor. Such institutions were common in Renaissance Venice and reflected the city's approach to social welfare.
Named after the church of Santa Maria della Carità or a charitable institution in this area of Dorsoduro. Venice had numerous charitable organizations and this name reflects that tradition.
A covered passageway where priests from nearby churches would often walk. Religious figures were common in the area around the Carmelite church in Dorsoduro.
Named after the Carmelite Order and their church (Santa Maria dei Carmini) in Dorsoduro. This directly connects to the referenced location of 'Calle dei Carmelitani'.
Named after the Church of San Barnaba in Dorsoduro. This was formerly a canal that was filled in to create a street, as was common in Venice's urban development.
Named after the craftsmen who made hoops for barrels, a crucial trade in wine-trading Venice. Barrel-making workshops were common in the working-class areas of Dorsoduro.

Named after the Priuli family, one of Venice's noble families who owned property in this area of Dorsoduro. Many Venetian streets bear the names of prominent families who lived or owned property nearby.
Named after the soap-making workshops that were once located in this part of Dorsoduro. Soap production was an important industry in Renaissance Venice.
Named after the Church of San Pantalon in Dorsoduro. The 'salizada' designation indicates it was one of the first paved streets in the area.
Named after a commandery, a property belonging to a military or religious order, likely related to the Carmelites or another order in Dorsoduro.
Named after Slavic traders or residents who lived in this area. Venice had strong connections with the eastern Adriatic coast, and many Slavic people lived and worked in the city.
Named after the cobblers who had workshops in this area of Dorsoduro. Shoe-making was an important craft in Renaissance Venice.
Named after a kiln or furnace that operated in this area of Dorsoduro. Kilns were used for various industries including ceramics and glassmaking.
Named after devotional practices related to the rosary, likely connected to the Dominican Church of Santa Maria del Rosario (Gesuati) in Dorsoduro.
A covered passageway named for its proximity to water or frequent flooding, a common issue in lower-lying areas of Venice including parts of Dorsoduro.
Named after the gondoliers who may have lived in this area of Dorsoduro. Gondoliers were essential to Venetian transportation and formed a distinct social group.
A poetic name for what was once a canal, possibly referring to a quiet area where scholars or religious figures from nearby institutions would walk in contemplation.
Named after the Scuola dei Carmini, a confraternity associated with the Carmelite church in Dorsoduro. This relates directly to the Carmelitani mentioned in the reference location.
Named after the Church of San Sebastiano in Dorsoduro, famous for its paintings by Paolo Veronese. This waterside walkway would have served as an important access point to the church.
Named after a monastery, possibly the Carmelite monastery, in this area of Dorsoduro. Monasteries were influential institutions in Renaissance Venetian society.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Pine Nuts
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after vendors who sold pine nuts, which were used in Venetian cuisine. The 'salizada' designation indicates it was among the first paved streets in the area.
Named after the Brustolon family, possibly referring to Andrea Brustolon, a famous Venetian sculptor and woodcarver whose works were found in churches and palaces throughout the city.
Named after the Ursuline nuns who had a convent in this area. This was once a canal that was filled in to create a street.
Named after lawyers who may have had their residences or offices in this area of Dorsoduro. Legal professionals were important in Venice's complex commercial and governance systems.
Named after the Rezzonico family, who owned the grand palace Ca' Rezzonico in Dorsoduro. This wealthy family rose to prominence in the 17th century.
Named after an old squero (boatyard) where gondolas and other boats were built and repaired. Several such boatyards existed in Dorsoduro due to its extensive waterfront.
A covered passageway named after rope makers who worked in the area. Rope making was essential for Venice's maritime economy, and workshops were often located in working-class areas of Dorsoduro.
Named after a small table or counter used by merchants, or possibly after a small devotional altar. This is a historically documented street name in Dorsoduro.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of Saints Gervasius and Protasius
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the Church of San Trovaso (a Venetian corruption of Saints Gervasius and Protasius) in Dorsoduro. This was once a canal that was filled to create a street.

Named after the guardians or caretakers of a nearby scuola (confraternity), possibly the Scuola dei Carmini in Dorsoduro. These officials were important in maintaining the scuola's buildings and operations.
Named after mooring posts used to secure boats along this waterfront in Dorsoduro. Such infrastructure was essential to Venice's water-based transportation system.
Named after flag bearers who participated in civic and religious processions. Processional displays were an important part of Venetian public life.
Named after a fontego (warehouse) that operated in this area. The 'salizada' designation indicates it was one of the first paved streets, likely due to commercial importance.
Named after converts or lay brothers associated with the Carmelite monastery in Dorsoduro. Religious conversions were significant events in Renaissance Venice.
Named after a capitello (small shrine or capital) that was a local landmark. This was once a canal that was filled in to create a street.
Named after a charitable institution or a religious artwork depicting the Pietà (the Virgin Mary cradling the dead body of Jesus). Works of mercy were central to Venetian religious life.
Named after the Ospedale degli Incurabili, a hospital in Dorsoduro that treated patients with diseases considered incurable in the Renaissance period.
Named after distinctive paving stones or a stonemason's workshop in this area of Dorsoduro. Stone was an important building material in Venice despite the city's lagoon setting.
A covered passageway named after the Catholic concept of Purgatory, possibly related to prayers or devotional practices at a nearby church in Dorsoduro.
Named after booksellers or printers who had shops in this area. Venice was a major center of printing and publishing in Renaissance Europe.
Named after the Church of Santa Maria della Salute in Dorsoduro, built as a votive offering for deliverance from the plague. This was once a canal that was filled in.
Named after hermits or recluses associated with religious orders in the area, possibly connected to the Carmelites who had traditions of eremitic spirituality.
Named after an abbey or a property belonging to an abbey that was located in this area of Dorsoduro.
Named after a shop sign depicting a parrot, or possibly after an actual parrot kept by a wealthy resident. Exotic birds were status symbols in Renaissance Venice.
Named after scholars or learned individuals who lived in the area, possibly connected to the University of Padua, where many Venetian nobili studied.
Named after velvet fabric merchants or workshops. Luxury textiles were a major industry in Renaissance Venice, with specialized workshops throughout the city.
Named after the institution for catechumens (converts preparing for baptism), particularly Jews and Muslims converting to Christianity. Venice had a specific institution for this purpose.
Named after an old scuola (confraternity) that was once located in this area of Dorsoduro. These institutions were important centers of social and religious life.
A covered passageway named after prayer practices, possibly connected to processions or devotional routines associated with the Carmelite church in Dorsoduro.
Named after gondoliers who operated ferry services at fixed crossing points of the Grand Canal. Several traghetti (ferry stations) existed along Dorsoduro's Grand Canal frontage.
Named after a long bridge that connected different parts of Dorsoduro. Bridges were crucial infrastructure in Venice's water-crossed urban landscape.
Named after artists who had their workshops in this area. Dorsoduro was home to many artists during the Renaissance, attracted by important church commissions.
Named after the Church of Angelo Raffaele in Dorsoduro. This was once a canal that was filled in to create a street, as indicated by the 'Rio Terà' designation.
Named after master craftsmen who had workshops in this area of Dorsoduro. Venice's economy relied heavily on specialized crafts organized into guilds.
Named after an institution for reformed prostitutes. Such institutions existed in Venice as part of the city's social welfare and moral reform efforts.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the Crooked Bell Tower
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after a leaning bell tower that was a local landmark. Venice's soft subsoil often caused structural issues in its buildings.
A covered passageway named after devout individuals who may have used this route to access the Carmelite church or other religious institutions in Dorsoduro.
Named after the Procurators of St. Mark, high-ranking Venetian officials who may have owned property in this area of Dorsoduro.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of the Little Nuns
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after a small convent or nuns from a particular order. This was once a canal that was filled in to create a street.
Named after craftsmen who worked in this area of Dorsoduro. Venice's economy depended heavily on skilled artisans across numerous trades.
Named after a monastery, possibly the Carmelite monastery, that had waterfront access at this location in Dorsoduro.
Named after a small passage or path that connected different areas in Dorsoduro. 'Pasina' is a Venetian dialect term for a small passage.
Named after devout individuals associated with religious institutions in the area. The 'salizada' designation indicates it was one of the first paved streets.
